\section{IV.I The Grand Canonical Ensemble}

The previous sections demonstrate that while the canonical and microcanonical ensembles are completely equivalent in the thermodynamic limit, it is frequently much easier to perform statistical mechanical computations in the canonical framework. Sometimes it is more convenient to allow chemical work (by fixing the chemical potential Î¼\muÎ¼, rather than at a fixed number of particles), but no mechanical work. The resulting macro-states Mâ‰¡(T,Î¼,x)M \equiv(T, \mu, \mathbf{x})Mâ‰¡(T,Î¼,x), are governed by the grand canonical ensemble. The corresponding microstates Î¼S\mu_{\mathrm{S}}Î¼Sâ€‹, contain an indefinite number of particles N(Î¼S).N\left(\mu_{\mathrm{S}}\right) .N(Î¼Sâ€‹). As in the case of the canonical ensemble, the system S\mathrm{S}S, can be maintained at a constant chemical potential through contact with a reservoir R\mathrm{R}R, at temperature TTT and chemical potential Î¼.\mu .Î¼. The probability distribution for the micro-states of S\mathrm{S}S is obtained by summing over all states of the reservoir, as in eq.(IV. 53))), and is given by
